clinical_study.brief_title: Posterior Cruciate Retaining (PCR) Versus Posterior Cruciate Substituting (PCS) Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
clinical_study.official_title: SCORPIO™ Posterior Stabilized Versus Posterior Retained Total Knee Arthroplasties: Long-term Functional and Radiographic Outcome

brief_summary.textblock: This randomized clinical trial (RCT) examined 10 year outcomes comparing SCORPIO™ Posterior Cruciate Substituting (PCS) versus Posterior Cruciate Retaining (PCR) Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) as the primary outcome.

detailed_description.textblock:
RCT of 100 subjects undergoing primary TKA who were randomized to received either a SCORPIO™ PCS or PCR TKA.
Subjects were evaluated pre-operatively and at 2 and 10 years post-operatively using the Western Ontario (WOMAC) Osteoarthritis Index, the RAND-36 and knee range of motion (2 years only). Complication and revision rates were also evaluated.

primary_outcome.time_frame: change in disease-specific quality of life from preoperative to 10 years postoperative
primary_outcome.description: disease-specific patient reported health related quality of life (pain and function)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: change in patient reported overall health status from preoperative to 10 years postoperative
secondary_outcome.description: generic patient reported health related quality of life measure

secondary_outcome.measure: Knee flexion and extension measured in degree
secondary_outcome.time_frame: change in knee flexion and extension measured in degreefrom preoperative to 2 years postoperative

arm_group.description: SCORPIO™ Posterior Cruciate Ligament Substituting TKA prosthesis
SCORPIO™ Posterior Cruciate Ligament Retaining TKA prosthesis

intervention.description: subjects randomized at surgery to receive 1 of the 2 specified implants

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- scheduled for primary TKA
- non-inflammatory arthritis
- intact Posterior Cruciate Ligament at the time of surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- required bone grafting of either the femur or tibia
- varus or valgus deformity of > 15 degrees
- previous high tibial osteotomy
- unable to understand or comply with the study requirements
- unable to provide signed informed consent
